posts.name: Nobre
posts.cooked:
Hey FRC community,

My name is Nobre. I'm a former FIRST LEGO League competitor and currently a mentor for FIRST teams in Brazil. Over the past few months, I've developed a tool called PathPlanner SPIKE, which adapts motion planning concepts from FIRST Robotics Competition's PathPlanner to the SPIKE Prime platform used in FIRST Lego League.

The motivation behind this project is to provide FIRST Lego League teams with advanced trajectory generation tools, reducing reliance on trial-and-error code and simplifying the creation of smooth, consistent autonomous routines. Similar to how PathPlanner empowers FIRST Robotics Competition teams, this tool offers comparable functionality in the FIRST Lego League context. It allows teams to design paths visually, generates Python code with a custom control library tailored to SPIKE Prime, and executes trajectories accurately on the competition field.

Why am I sharing this with the FIRST Robotics Competition community? Because your expertise could significantly enhance the project—especially in areas like trajectory following, backend structure improvements, and creating a user-friendly interface inspired by the PathPlanner GUI.

My future goals include expanding support for SPIKE sensors, adapting to various FIRST Lego League strategies, enhancing the user interface, and providing comprehensive documentation. The tool is still in development but is already functional and open-source. You can explore it at [GitHub link].

If you're interested in contributing, have suggestions, or want to collaborate, feel free to reach out. My email is nobrecoding@gmail.com.

Looking forward to your insights and our collective efforts to create something impressive!

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
The current meta in FRC for differential drive pose feedback control is LTVUnicycleController (WPILib API 2025.3.2) feeding velocity commands to two wheel velocity P controllers. Pure pursuit has a lot of theoretical and practical downsides. Furthermore, LTVDifferentialDriveController (WPILib API 2025.3.2) offers better performance but requires complex physical modeling. LTVUnicycleController and LTVDifferentialDriveController are challenging to implement. An LQR implementation in Python is provided below:

```python
import numpy as np
import scipy as sp

def lqr(A, B, Q, R):
    P = sp.linalg.solve_discrete_are(A, B, Q, R)
    return np.linalg.solve(B.T @ P @ B + R, B.T @ P @ A)
```

Alternatively, RobotPy provides Python wrappers for WPILib functions, though leveraging it may be complex.

link_counts.title: Paper: Implementation of the Adaptive Pure Pursuit Controller

posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver

posts.name: Nobre
posts.cooked: For an FLL robot, I believe that Pure Pursuit is already more than sufficient in terms of accuracy and performance, especially considering the table size, type of challenges, and hardware limitations. Unfortunately, it’s not possible to directly reuse WPILib in the SPIKE Prime environment because it’s a closed system with limited processing power and library compatibility. That’s why I’m currently exploring the possibility of expanding the project to also support Pybricks, which offers much more freedom and could potentially allow the integration of more robust concepts like LQR, with some level of optimization.

Looking forward to collaborating!

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: it’s a closed system with limited processing power. After exploring this further, I believe you won’t have access to many modern features regardless of the programming language chosen or how much optimization is applied. The roboRIO 2.0 equipped with an 866 MHz dual-core ARM Cortex-A9 CPU struggles to execute cutting-edge features in Java and Python, whereas the SPIKE Prime, featuring a 100 MHz ARM Cortex-M4 CPU, falls short based on its specifications.

posts.name: Nobre
posts.cooked: You’re absolutely right—the SPIKE Prime’s hardware is very limited, and I completely agree that running complex FRC-grade motion planning systems like LTV controllers or full-blown LQR isn’t realistic. But just to clarify, my goal isn’t to replicate the full capabilities of modern FRC motion planning. What I’m aiming to do is build a simplified version—a “mini PathPlanner”—that works well within the constraints of FLL. Pure Pursuit, basic smoothing, and a simple PID control layer are more than enough for the scale of the game table and the type of challenges we face in FLL. My goal is practicality—saving time, improving reliability, and helping teams avoid tedious trial-and-error path tuning. Additionally, part of my focus right now is to study all these motion planning approaches and choose the best platform to implement them. Currently, I’m developing the tool as a web-based prototype, but my long-term goal is to transform it into a standalone app, similar to the official FRC PathPlanner, with a better interface and more features. I really appreciate your insights and technical feedback—it helps me stay grounded on what makes sense for the platform!
